125,CREA125,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Self-employed,ERGO CREO,"Via San Leonardo 8, 37128 Verona, Italy","BUSINESS SERVICES, MANUFACTURING",B2B,8,1,YES,IN,Pierluigi Di Giovanni,"A new emerging business sector, also referred to as the 3rd Industrial revolution, is based on additive manufacturing technologies. The new players in this field are the creative minds (industrial designers, architects, graphic designers, artists etc.) who are open to learn and take advantage of a new process of fabrication. Only those professionals who have a full understanding of digital software tools are able to express their potential and to be competitive, bringing innovative products to market in a smart and cost efficient way. Nowadays the creativity of many people remains hidden and unexpressed because of the steep learning curve in mastering 3D modeling applications, only few can cover this gap and access additive manufacturing hardware technology.

The aim of this project is to reduce the gap existing between digital and physical fabrication process through the implementation of a user friendly 3D data navigation and manipulation protocol. There are 3 tools playing a key role in the digital craftsman?s laboratory: 3D modeling software packages and 3D printing/scanning hardware. The integration of these technologies requires skills and know-how.

Our business idea consists of a web-based platform which will enable 3D modelers to connect with creative minds in order to translate their ideas into physical models and thereby empowering a business relationship. The process of taking a design concept from its original sketch to its final shape requires a lengthy workflow of exchanging information and data between the designer and the 3D modeler. The physical distance between the two makes communication not only time consuming, but also costly. At present, the exchange of information is mostly carried out by verbal communication, email attachments and with personal meetings. The main limitation of this process lies in the difficulty of not being able to display, modify, render and discuss actions and issues related to the model in real-time.

Therefore we are proposing a cost-effective way of designing and co-creating digital models, in a synchronized way, within a shared digital workspace which is not bound to the software used by the modeler and is independent from the physical location of the involved partners and of the production facilities.

The platform will on one side offer software applications to its subscribers, on the other intermediate between the 3D scanning/printing service providers. Our community members will benefit from this all-in-one offer as they will deliver a complete service to their customers.

The software package we intend to use and that will be at the core of our web-based services is FIWARE, this can be further developed and potentially re-sold as a new API, transferrable to different business sectors.

We forecast the usage of this service principally, but not only, by two categories of users: 3D printing enthusiasts who approach this technology for the first time and need full support for taking their design idea to production and designers who know the technology but do not know how to properly use the software tool best suited for their project. On the other hand we hypothesize that there will be two types of platform experts who will offer their competences as a service: technical 3D modelers who will make models following the client?s specification and 3D modelers who will also offer their personal design style for improving aesthetically, functionally or ergonomically the outlook of the product. Each modeler registered on the platform will have a dedicated profile showing products, projects and ratings received by her/his clients.",Tech provider,,0,0,0,0,0,,Software,Mechanical Computer-Aided Design,Applications,Engineering Applications,1,0,#N/A,Startup,50000,0

126,CREA126,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Spine,"Spine, interactive library for designers","Via Santa Teresa 47, 37135 Verona, Italy","ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT AND RECREATION, BUSINESS SERVICES",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Ivan Favalezza,"The problem
I?m a graphic designer and I love visual books. Designers are constantly look for visual books. Design manuals, rarities, monographs, classics, catalogs.
They don?t just look for them. They dream on them. And they need ?em for work and for study.
The last time I was in a design library I passed one hour in, just because it?s an immersive and a beautiful experience.
ÿ
The problem is that theese books are not online. There is no digital version of them.
It's impossible to digitize them because they are special. They have different papers, transparencies, emboss finishes, special paints. So they are impossible to translate in a digital product.
ÿ
The solution
The solution is an interactive visual library for designers, artists, photograpers and architects. It?s called Spine.
ÿ
The process

We take design books in consignment from publishers. We take Hi Res pictures of all pages of the books and we transform them into a ebooks. So a real book becomes an Hi quality ebook. The photo process show details that normally are hidden in standard ebooks. This digital product It's provided with a user interface. You can zoom, search, browse. And you can read it as well. It is a unitary product and it's marketable as a standard ebook.
ÿ
Online.
Registred users can enjoy the Ebooks we make for 15 minutes for free as in a normal bookshop. (Time limit.)
If they want they can have a premium account for a 15 ? / monthly fee or buy the single ebook.
70% goes to Spine and 30% goes to publishers in proportions to the number of pages visited.
The model is different from Spotfy because there is no ads in here. It's an ""All You Can Eat"" business model.
ÿ
Premium users can enjoy the whole library on every platform.

Publishers, on the other side, can directly relate with an online community and an international niche receptive to the purchase of the hard copy of the original books. This operation will be facilitated and promoted by Spine.
We are also acting as dropshipers for the purchase of the hardcopy of the books.
For the first six months Spine will contracts with publishers interested in the project.ÿ
We have strong validation of interest with a few number of them.
The goal will be to photograph and digitize 300 titles in the first 8 months.
This time will be long enough to build a working prototype of the platform with a Fi-Ware powered back-end.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

127,CREA127,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Startup,Friendipity,"via Dell'Albera 8, house, 38121 Trento, Italy",Horizontal (solutions suitable for every verticals),0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Luca Pappaglione,"Friendipity synchronizes calendars across you and your friends, to let you know what they?re going to do and where, in the next future, to manage the spare time together.

Friendipity allows you to share your public appointments and events, letting your friends know what you are going to do and, if they want, join you. Or, at the opposite, it allows you to join your friends if they are going to do something interesting.
There are similar working-based tools, useful to organize meetings with your co-worker team, eg. Outlook, Google calendar, iCal, Lotus, but none of these is thought for free time.
ÿ
In a busy world, where social networks have imposed almost exclusively virtual relations, Friendipity wants to reinstate the real ones.
How many times have we missed hanging out with friends because we didn?t know their plans? How many times did this happen because we didn?t have time to text or call them?
ÿ

Reaching a large part of our friends to know or to let them know the reciprocal plans, forces us to write countless sms (in countless whatsapp groups), or to make lots of calls, which is sometimes boring and other times hard to do (when we are at work, at school, or at the university).
ÿ

Friendipity solves all these problems, letting people know what will happen around them. It won?t be only a virtual window on our friend?s life, satisfying our curiosity, but, more consistently, it will push us to get out and be more active in the real life, knowing immediately what our friends are going to do. We will then avoid regrets, like knowing too late, from the social networks, that we missed something nice that some friends did/organized the night/day before, while we could have been there if we knew it.
ÿ

The will to integrate social-networks into real life is not new: companies like Facebook (Nearby Friends), Google (ex Google Latitude) and Foursquare (Swarm), are trying to achieve this goal focusing only on the ?here and now?, with a check-in on a map. Well, like this it?s too late! When I check-in, I?m already doing something and I don?t allow my friends to know in advance where I am, to reach me. Otherwise, when I see someone else checking-in, it might be too late to reach him. Friendipity, on the contrary, lets people know in advance what friends are planning, to ?carpe diem? any occasion.

Furthermore, in the existing social networks, the single user has often a community of contacts too big (way over the relationships one is able to manage) to feel confortable in sharing such private information as location and schedules. Friendipity is, instead, designed for smaller groups of real friends.
ÿ

Friendipity could also help: (1) giving you a chance to meet with a girl or a boy you are interested in, knowing where She/He is going to be (being particularly careful with privacy issue), (2) allowing you to meet friends who live abroad, who are in the nearby for work/holiday for just a few days, (3) simplifying the family routine (I know a couple that use one spreadsheet in Google Drive to know the partner?s appointments to schedule their own agenda), (4) managing amateur or professional sport team?s appointments and presence during the season.
ÿ

Friendipity will be almost always used in mobility. That?s why we started developing the App for iOS (XCode), using Parce for managing the backend, and we will proceed for Android. Then a standard web browser application will follow, to add a more manageable platform.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

128,CREA128,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Startup,INMOVIEMENT,"Via dei volsci N. 34, 00185 Rome, Italy",TELECOM AND MEDIA,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,gabriele oricchio,"InMovieMent is a web platform where users are involved in all creative steps to make a movie, starting from the ?idea? up to its production and distribution .

We will offer the independent film industry some projects selected from a community of movie fans that will give their feedback during all productive stages of a film (writing, casting, locations, cinematography, costumes, music).
in this way We will help the industry to optimize its investments.
We will support the young filmakers and their crews to personalize the best feedback to create successful films.
We will give the users the possibility to share emotional and educational experiences as well.
ÿ
In the long term:
Identify, co-produce, and produce successful films including the community whether through crowdsourcing and crowfounding.
ÿ

The main aim of this project it's not simply present an idea to the audience and involve them, but try to understand the unconscious that creates this story in the audience and merge this unconscious as much as possible with the author's one.ÿ We want to Achieve this by Identifying a list of key visual images and semantic codes specifically created on each movie genre and subgenre.

Trough Those codes we want to summarize and create a visual map of all audience's emotional and logical feedbacks and drive the artist in the creation of them to more attractive product to the market.

Therefore, the large investment of this prototype is to reunite some scientists and cinema industry people (anthropologist, semiotician, director of photography, scriptwriter, producer, director, cinema critic, neurolinguistic experts) to identify universal visual and semantic codes that represent each genre and sub-genre of cinema.ÿ All this research opens a business even bigger:ÿ

The idea that a user, through his participation to all the steps ÿof a movie, can sum up his ""cinematographic unconscious"" in a sort of a QR code (that summarize his emotional map) can open the way to new and faster methods of classification and search.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A
129,CREA129,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Startup,PizzaUp,"via marzola 10, 38050 calceranica al lago, Italy",ACCOMMODATION AND FOOD SERVICE ACTIVITIES,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Francesco Mazzarol,"ÿÿ
PizzaUp is an application designed for the electronic management of orders in the scope of take-away pizzas.
Currently pizzerias are having to manage a considerable number of phone orders, often resulting in a substantial waste of time.

On the other hand, ordering by phone for customers may result cumbersome. In fact it may be difficult to retrieve information about the pizzeria, for example the timetable, phone number or its menu.ÿ In this case it is required a web search to retrieve the information for contacting the pizzeria, then a phone call is required for knowing the menu. This results in a waste of time for both customer and pizzeria.
PizzaUp is a system that aims to embrace both the needs of pizzerias and of customers.
ÿ
Benefits for pizzerias:
increase the visibility thanks to the presence of a map that will show all pizzerias in a given area
ability to create an introductory page in which to describe their menu, timetable and all the information to share with customers

time optimization: the order will be displayed on a tablet by which the pizzeria will be able to get all information about the order such as the identity of the customer, location, delivery time etc. It will be possible to decide whether to accept or reject or delay the order
recognition of the identity of the client so that it can be reported as ""unwanted"" in case of any jokes or abuse of service
the order will be printed by POS printer in order to speed up the process of ordering
improve its services by analyzing the reviews written by customers
opportunity to promote special events (e.g. happy hour) directly on the smartphone customer opening a new promotional channel at low cost.
ÿ
Benefits for customers:
opportunity to get the menu of every pizzeria and to customize the pizzas (if allowed by the pizzeria)
ability to search for a pizza place according with several criteria, such as the availability of gluten-free foods
ability to hide the restaurants that are not currently opened
reduce the time of the ordering process because of the immediate availability of all the needed information
customers can place their order from smartphones, tablets, and PCs in whatever place they are (even if they are not able to perform a call, e.g. office, university classes, trains or crowded places)
no call charges to place an order
opportunity to discover new pizzerias when moving in non-habitual locations
to review the various pizzerias and read the reviews written by other customers.
ÿ
The team of PizzaUp will provide in loan to each pizzeria:
a tablet for managing orders
a printer for commands
a few months of service
flyers to promote the service.
ÿ
After the first period in which PizzaUp service will be free, every pizzeria will have to bear the cost of this service (flat fee or per usage).

It will be possible to advertise pizzerias by banner ad, in order to introduce more users into their business. This banner will entail costs, which will be significantly lower than the cost required by printing and distributing flyers.
ÿ
We will use the technologies proposed by Fi-Ware (in particular the Virtualization) in order to implement the services of data-storage and computing required by the system.
In addition, all non-sensitive data will be made public through appropriate API (also implemented via Fi-Ware) to expand the context in which they can be used (Open Data).
A concrete example could be data-mining on the tastes of the customers clustered by geographical areas or ethnic groups, but there are tons of possible usages.

130,CREA130,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Startup,Wrapping Reality,"via maccani , 42, 38121 Trento, Italy",TELECOM AND MEDIA,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Marco Soave,"Multimedia content represents a key element in 2.0 web. One of the web 2.0 greatest strengths is its dynamic and interactive nature. Video and picture, instead, did not change the way you access and interact with: these are still tied up with the old and traditional journalistic and television broadcasting model where the users are merely passive.

The Wrapping Reality project is aimed at changing this approach, producing immersive, user-centered multimedia content, enhancing the users interaction in media material fruition. The resulting experience is hence much more engaging and exciting, transmitting the desired message in an efficient and effective way. Arrays of High Definition (HD) cameras will produce panoramic (360 degrees) and spheric (360 x 360 degrees) pictures and video streams, both two dimensional (2DWR) or three dimensional (3DWR). These can be reproduced either by various traditional or new conception devices type, providing users with innovative and addictive experiences.

The main goal ÿof the Wrapping Reality(WR) project is the development of a complete workflow, starting from video acquisition, terminating with user content exploration and including all the intermediate steps like panoramic content processing and management.

Cameras arrays together with sensor sets like accelerometers and gyroscopes allow to link the acquired content with a specific and precise geographical location. Furthermore it is possible to process the acquired content by means of advanced image processing techniques, adding additional information or applying a stack of custom developed special effects (SFX). In the latest stage of the project efforts will be made to the implementation of image stabilization and enhancement SFX ÿlike Hyper-Lapse and High Dynamic Range (HDR).
Remote storage and streaming technique are high priority developments, together with 2DWR and 3DWR real time broadband broadcasting technologies.

The recorded content is suited for a multitude of input-output stimulus arrangements. The navigation in space and time along the recorded ?panoramic video tunnels? (PVTs) will be performed by means of mouse and keyboard combination, joystick/gamepad devices but also utilising innovative motion detection devices like Leap Motion or Microsoft Kinect. Natural interaction techniques are much more intuitive, attractive and capable of catalyzing the attention of users. Virtual reality head-mounted displays like Oculus Rift will complete the user experience immersing users in an insulated full-field-of-view virtual world.

It is possible an input method on mobile devices touchscreens but, considering the user-surrounding nature of the WR content, move the digital world viewport using information provided by gyroscopes and accelerometers will result in appreciable user experience. The market release of add-ons like Samsung Gear Vr or the simpler Google CardBoard permit a Oculus-like experience, as well as cheaper and wireless.

Concurrent multi-user collaboration and interaction along the PVTs is possible, being the content stored on remote servers and streamed on demands. The server knows the exact viewing position of all the active users and can share this information with a group of collaborators: each user can be aware of the PVT portion other users are looking at. The union with a voice or text chat produce an efficient and entertaining environment exploration tool.

Being the PVT fully georeferenced it can be enriched with additional information about the captured environment (points of interests/POIs). Interactive elements linked to well defined position of the PVT will appear during the users experience, enabling interaction with additional information in order to increase knowledge about the object or to trigger specific actions.

It is possible to exploit the great amount of recorded data producing video edits featured with unique special effects like strong stabilization, time freezing, great changes in camera field of view and spatial re-projection. The resulting videos are intended for a passive vision on standard monitors, although and even better results can be appreciated on autostereoscopic 3D ones having great impressing and attracting ability.

The whole processes chain involved in the project implies the generation and processing of a big amount of digital data, the development of many web services and the design of some user interfaces and applications
column2: FIWARE enablers ecosystem capabilities will simplify and speed up the prototyping phase, while FI-lab will allow fast testing and experimentation of the developed components.

column1: 131,CREA131,CREA,CREAtiFi,Greece,Startup,DigiFI,"Ag. Ioanni Ksenou 38, 73100 Chania, Greece",Consumer leisure/gaming,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Stelios Sotiriadis,"Today 200,000+ images make their way to Facebook alone every minute and 27,800 photos are uploaded to Instagram every minuteÿand in generalÿ880 BILLION photos will be taken in 2014 if we continue on the current trend. There seems that, smart city citizens live their lives by time-stamping their moments with a photo and post it to social sites.ÿDigiFIÿwill create a FIWARE based service that will offer incentives to everyday users for sharing digital artefacts that they use or produce. DigiFI will form an added value art business model by definingÿthe future Internet copyright and micro-payment service model for FI producers and consumers of digital art over the public Internet. We aim to develop FIWARE services:

Allowing digital art (images, paintings, 3d objects, 3D artifacts, archeological artifacts, and other) that captured and shared by Smart City users in their everyday activities to be easily delivered to interested parties over FIWARE technology.
Supporting augmented reality features to increase representation detail.
Defining copyrights on the fly that could be used from 3rd party users, applications or services on demand and on pay-as-you-go model.
Processing automatic payments via a number of payment methods, eg. PayPal.
Monitoring of increasing usage, ratings and popularity of digital objects will ensure quality of service.
Monitoring usage of Google Alert will prevent content theft and will notify for unregistered usage of digital objects.
The idea is rather simple but with high potentials and desribed as follows:
A user (known as a producer) takes a photo and post it to social site (e.g. using instagram API)

A consumer uses the DigiFI-Art service to register the photo, define copyrights and micro-payment mode (e.g. using paypal API). Consumer will use the copyrights (set by producer) on demand, define subscription period and make use of the photo on demand.ÿThe DigiFI system will generate the location (URI) of the photo (in JSON format to be incorporated automatically within his/her application using the REST protocol) along with a token that is valid for one month so the consumer uses the photo within his/her application.
Consumer users browses photos from the service, and selects to use it based on a subscription period (e.g. use the photo for a small cost).

DigiFI is responsible for maintaining revenue distribution among parties using a publish subscribe broker. Also it providesÿpatterns and rules for event management (e.g. increasing usage of objects will affect related costs, Complex Event Processingÿwill identify such patterns and will provide rules).

The sustainability of the project is high since automatic business flows will allow payments to be made to digiFI in terms of a small percentage, and rest will go to the photo owner. Other 3rd party service providers e.g. paypal etc. will be paid according to their usage by the DigiFI-Art based on usage.ÿ",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

132,CREA132,CREA,CREAtiFi,Greece,Startup,NotiFI,"A. Ioanni Xenou 38, 73100 Chania, Greece",Consumer other,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Stelios Sotiriadis,"NotiFI is a Future Internet project to expand the news distribution brokering market. Specifically, it is aÿNews Subscription service that allows News Brokers (Information Producers) to easily publish their news in form of text, images, sound and video while News Consumers could be subscribed and get data dynamically and on demand. We are motivated by the openings arising and the possibilities of applying FI technology in this field by offeringÿpurpose build instantiations of the NotiFI service.ÿThe service will offer:
a) Instant publication of the news while subscribers receive content dynamically in the form of a subscription to a RESTFul service.
b) Instant access to material for registered consumers and reactive payment settlement among brokers and consumers based on a dynamic revenue settlement service.

c) Transformation of news to API in terms of categorization of information and exposition of interfaces based on the REST protocol. It will be aÿcloud platform service to act as an API for third party applications, services and users.

d) Cloud based modular structure of the system to ensure elasticity and flexibility. Developers implementing new solutions or already existing news systems (web sites, applications, mobile apps etc.) could use the NotiFIÿservice to allow interaction of consumers, yet by simple calling the API to get information on the form of aÿlightweight data-interchange format (e.g. JSON).
e) Identification of user needs and trends, information that will be offered to Brokers as a Service in order to assist them to increase businesses and identify target users.
ÿ
The following scenario demonstrates the business idea and the revenue flows.

a) A News Broker register to the NotiFI service and gets a token for remote communication. At this stage the Information Producer setup the payment data (e.g. by PayPal to receive income) while makes a payment to the DigiFI service for usage.
b) Using the token it publish news to the NotiFI service:
ÿ ÿ - By using the NotiFI platform orÿ
ÿ ÿ - By calling the NotiFI service remotely using the token
c) Information Consumers register also to the NotiFI platform and pay the fees for usage.

d) Select the information they want to be subscribed (by browsing categories e.g. each time an article about technology will be published a RESTFul based service will update the content of the consumer application or system).

e) The Consumer pays the subscription fees to the NotiFI service that arranges the payments with the Broker. The first period (e.g. 6-12 months) NotiFI service will be offered as free of charge to News Brokers in order to provide motives for usage.
f) The Consumer gets a token that it is valid until the end of the subscription and it is associated with the Broker and the categories that the Consumer selected at previous steps.
ÿ

NotiFI service has already identifies a News Broker and a number of Consumers based on the GoodNews.gr system that is the first journalistic agency in Greecewith good news. In particular, GoodNews.gr will be the use case of the NotiFI project in order to demonstrate effectiveness and reach target market within a small amount of time. NotiFI will expand GoodNews.gr system to offer:
a) Integration with other systems: An efficient API to integrate the systems and run business more efficiently.ÿ
b) To take control: The NotiFIÿAPI will provide the tools for subscribers to interface into news and personalize their systems according to the things that better suits their needs.

c) Engage customers and vendors: NotiFI will provideÿan API in other systems to allow Consumers (and their applications) to make minor tweaks without the costly expenditures of buying new software.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

134,CREA134,CREA,CREAtiFi,Hungary,Startup,Sellysium,"N‚pfrd” utca 17/c 2. emelet 6., 1138 Budapest, Hungary","BUSINESS SERVICES, MANUFACTURING",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,G bor Vargyai,"Sellysium.com is a real-time, fully integrated marketplace engine and order management platform. Crafters, designers and manufacturing companies (from now on they are called Suppliers) can use the platform in the following way:
ÿ
They upload their products to the platform using a simple excel file (in MVP phase) ro by using our API.
They set the price they want to get for the products.
They select which countries and languages they would like to sell their products in.
They let us know whether they would like to use their own logistics solution or the one offered by Sellysium.com.
They submit all information and they are done.
ÿ

Once a supplier submits the product information, our platform sends all the texts and descriptions to a partner company, who make sure that these are translated to all selected languages by native speakers.
After the translations are in place, the products appear in the listing on our platform where web shop owners (from now on: Merchants) can see them.
ÿ

On the other side of the value chain there are the web shop owners, who would like to widen their product portfolio, or harness the power of cross selling, but who do not have the option to purchase a large amount of inventory upfront.
ÿ

Merchants have to register to our platform, and integrate our APIs to their own web shop. For major web shop rental platforms like Shopify.com they do not have to do the integration as our modules can already be found in the system and we can also provide them with modules for the most widely used web shop and CMS platforms like WordPress, Drupal, Joomla, Magento, etc.
ÿ

When the integration is done, the merchant simply logs into our system and browses the products available in their country. When she selected the products she actually wants to display in her web shop, she updates the price with her profit and saves the changes.
ÿ

The selected product immediately appears in her web shop through our API and is available for customers to be purchased. When an order is placed for a product the API notifies the Sellysium platform about the purchase so that can forward the order to the supplier. In the meantime our platform sends all the order details to the selected logistics partner which will send a courier for the package by the given time and delivers it to the customer.
ÿ
There are two main options to monetize the solution.
ÿ
Suppliers pay a small, 5% commission fee after all sales that they received through the platform.
Merchants can be charged for a monthly fee depending on the number of products they wish to display in their store.
ÿ

On the long run there are many different ways to extend the platform and its incomes. In case there are many products in certain product categories, we can introduce a model where Suppliers pay for highlighting their products on the top of the listing.
ÿ

A different approach for the platform extension is a vertical expansion. In this case we can offer the platform to many different industries. From the very beginning we designed the platform in a way that it can easily be adjusted in case of a pivot of the target audience.
ÿ

It does not matter if the Suppliers are hotels who want to sell hotel bookings and Merchants are travel agencies, or the Suppliers are event organizers who sell tickets for concerts and other events, and the Merchants are different ticket portals.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A
135,CREA135,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Startup,Shelpy,"Via orti 6, 32030 Fonzaso , BL, Italy",Consumer health/wellness,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Caterina De Bacco,"I.Business Idea

Have you have had to drive you grandmother grocery shopping because she can?t drive? Did you need to change your plans to do this? Perhaps when you arrived at the shop you met somebody leaving in her neighborhood?what if he could have given a lift to her or better, buy all the things she needed himself and then carry the bags directly to her places stopping by on the way back!
Is the closest shop 10km far away from your home and you currently can?t go shopping that far? Perhaps your neighbor can.

These situations are commonly experienced by people living in mountain territories, where small towns lack of shops and to reach the closest ones you need to climb down with your car to the valley below. But what if you don?t have a car nor the possibility to go shopping? Usually you need your relatives to help you and come all the way up to your place
column2: you don?t want to bother a neighbor for that, even though he goes up and down the valley everyday to go to work. In principle, he could carry some bags for you once he goes shopping for himself, thing that he has to do anyway at some point of the week. Wouldn?t it be helpful?

column1: Our idea is to create a web application (and the corresponding mobile version) in the form of a web platform where residents of mountain villages that need to go shopping but can?t for any kind of mobility problems, can find other residents leaving nearby that offer their help going shopping for the previous ones. These volunteers will then deliver the bags directly at the home of the people who requested the help. The idea is that these volunteers have to go shopping for themselves anyway at some point of the week, therefore if we manage to get them involved and propose their help we could then match needs and helps so to optimize the action of going grocery shopping for both of the two parties involved.

The main objective of our service is thus to offer all sorts of web features that could allow the establishment and the optimal implementation of these solidarity exchanges between people who need and people who offer their help to perform the basic need of grocery shopping.
The customers of our service are two types: shoppers, who need to be delivered shopping bags
column2: volunteers, who offer to go shopping and then deliver the bags on the way back. We will denote by user either of the two, meaning a general user of our service. From now on we will use these two terms with the meaning we just defined above.

column1: Examples of main features our platform might use are: register and authenticate users
column2: provide a request form for people who need help and a corresponding form to write the list shop they need
column3: provide a search for users based on given criteria
column4: propose deals and offers provided by local shops
column5: estimate shop list cost and gasoline expenses.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

141,CREA141,CREA,CREAtiFi,Italy,Tailoritaly,Tailoritaly,"piazza bianco 20, 75100 matera, Italy","MANUFACTURING, WHOLESALE AND RETAIL TRADE
column2: REPAIR OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Monica Calicchio,"COMPANY

column1: TailorItalyis the first fashion platform that engages a global audience in the best web experience of Italian fashion world, right to the deepest dream of style enthusiasts. We let customers personalize their clothes and accessories choosing color, fabric and shape. We find the most innovative Italian SMEs and artisans and connect them to worldwide customers creating great content to promote our ecosystem across new markets. Clients that are not physically in Italycan have access to artisans exclusive products and first quality fabric and design. ÿBy designing and producing 100% of our items on the Italian factory floor, TailorItalydistributes a rare premium product that demonstrates the power of history, tradition and passion needed to create a Timeless Piece.
ÿ
MARKET

Growth in the European Fashion Market is driven by e-commerce: +77% in the last 4 years vs a 4% increase in the total fashion market. Luxury online fashion is forecasted to increase by 20% CAGR. Looking forward over the next four years, eCommerce sales penetration will accelerate to 10% in 2016 that is about four times the rate of traditional retail sales. This inflection will be driven by high-growth emerging markets such as Russia and Latin America as well as the destabilization of specialty retail in developed markets, particularly within the US and Australia. Total Addressable Market for online fashion is 34bn Euro for the European Market. (Data by Morgan Stanley and Eurostat)
ÿ
MARKET OPPORTUNITY

In Italythere are around 80,000 SMEs in the fashion industry ÿin the textile and leather sectors and 35% of the available machines are not in use (ISTAT). This unused capacities are caused by two main factors:
1) The competition of the cheap&amp
column2: chic sector has caused a war on price that is not helping the recovery

column1: of the industry after the last two years in decline.
2)Collapse of internal demand. Indeed, over the last 5 years internal market has decreased by 20%. However the positive trend is that exports have increased by 38% and they will rise to 76% by 2015.
To boost this trend, TailorItalyexploits Made in Italyfashion districts quality of material, expertise and unused resources giving them a new Business Channel to scale their revenues. ÿ
ÿ
COMPETITION
We enter in the online fashion luxury segment targeting style enthusiasts who are innovative and express themselves through fashion.

TailorItalyuniqueness is in the variety of product offered thanks to a network of first quality fashion producers, in the customization options offered to the final customers that have the feeling to be in a real Italian tailor, and in the high quality for a lower price.
Major competitors can be identified in TinkerTailor, Tailor4Less, Itailor, Net-a-Porter, Yoox,Shoes of Prey.
ÿ
VALUE PROPOSITION AND COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE
TailorItalycompetitive advantage can be summarized in the following 3 points:

TailorItalyconnects fashion producers directly to the final customers, shortens the value chain and cuts costs by 60%. TailorItalytakes an average commission on sale of 40%, and producers get 50% more than producing B2B.
Made to order: producers personalize and ship only after receiving the order. Lean business model and low logistic costs.
Monica, CEO&amp
column2: Founder, has 3 years experience as Marketing and Business Intelligence Manager in Rocket Internet fashion startups in Australia and Germany. Monica was part of the funding team of Theiconic.com.au ( Rocket Fashion Startups) where she was responsible for developing cross-departemantal strategies for Marketing, Merchandising and Operations. Monica has the experience to launch a digital business, to manage it and to make it profitable.

column1: 142,CREA142,CREA,CREAtiFi,UK,Smartzer LTD,Smartzer,"4-5 hazlitt mews, hazlitt road, w140jz london","Consumer other, WHOLESALE AND RETAIL TRADE
column2: REPAIR OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Karoline Gross,"Smartzer aims to provide a seamless shopping experience through interactive ?shoppable? videos in both online and offline environments.

column1: ÿ

The problem is that retailers and brands cannot fulfil the needs for their customers who want to shop items featured in videos created by the brands, in a user friendly, seamless and measurable way. Smartzer puts strong emphasis on creating a frictionless consumer journey from videos to purchase, reducing the number of clicks required to purchase from 18 to 1 (for John Lewis example).ÿ
ÿ

Through some basic trials, we are now developing a shoppable content based personalised marketing service. Video viewers will be able to click on items they like in videos, which will be added to a wishlist. This wishlist is then emailed to the customer as well as the brand. The customer can shop from the email and the brand receives deep insights into individual customer preferences as well as building a highly personal relationship with customers.ÿ
ÿ

144,CREA144,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Hehku Pikatulkkipalvelu Oy,Interpreter Company Service (ICS),"Ankkurinvarsi 12 c 6, 02320 Espoo, Finland","ACCOMMODATION AND FOOD SERVICE ACTIVITIES, Consumer other, PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION AND DEFENCE
column2: COMPULSORY SOCIAL SECURITYÿÿÿ",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Matti J„ntti,"The current business of interpreting companies is very important and challenging at the same time. There are millions of tourists and travelers which travel around the world. However the need for communication is very essential in the destination countries for tourists or foreigners. The real assistance of human interpreters is needed especially in situations where the foreigner needs help with the doctor, police, even shopping or other possible situations. This is where interpreting companies come to the play. Though, the current outdated and complicated manual operation model that current interpreting companies have, does not allow them to assist individuals. Hiring private interpreter for tourists and travelers is very costly and difficult.

column1: ÿ

We have a solution that can solve all above mentioned issues, and connect tourists or foreigners to interpreters easily. ICS, can make this process cheaper and at the same time quicker for both interpreter companies and individual travelers. ICS is the service which gives the ability to tourists or any other individual or organization that need language assistance. In this system, customer can search for the desired language that he/she is looking for and book the available interpreter for specific time by just few clicks or touch of mobile phone. The interpreters are getting feedback from customers that can help other customers to choose easily the best interpreters. Moreover, the feedback can help the owners of interpreting companies to increase their quality.
ÿ

Customers can pay by most common payment methods through the service or for organizations there is possibility of monthly invoicing. ICS, stays in the middle of interpreting companies, and customers which can reduce the use of operators in the current interpreting company systems, and consequently reduce the cost and increase efficiency.
ÿ

In the current interpreting business model, customer should call to the interpreting company and ask for an interpreter, then the interpreting company should call the interpreter and ask for his/her availability and then call back the customer to inform whether there is available interpreter or not. However this is not efficient and time consuming for both parties, which ICS tries to solve it. With ICS, all the operations happens automatically and everything becomes computerized. ÿ

column2: REPAIR OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOTORCYCLES",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Michaˆ Gasior,"Qute is an innovative mobile application which gives instant fashion advice to users on what to buy or what to wear. Users of Qute can easily turn their fashion-related everyday decisions into fun. The mobile nature of the app helps user break down geographical barriers and get instant advice on what to buy, wherever they are and wherever they shop at the moment.

146,CREA146,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Omakirja Oy,Omakirja Data Mill,"c/o Norkkokuja 9 C 13, 00790 Helsinki, Finland",Horizontal (solutions suitable for every verticals),0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Omakirja Oy,"According EMC (http://www.emc.com).ÿ ""If you average out the different analysts' predictions, it is expected that about 15 percent of all IT spending will move the cloud-that is, to as-a-Service delivery models-by 2015, growing to about 35 percent by 2021. Provided that the Big Data market reaches the $17 billion target by 2015, the Big Data-as-a-Service market will therefore be 15 percent of that figure, or $2.55 billion. With an estimated Big Data market of about $88 billion in 2021, the Big Data-as-a-Service market will be 35 percent of that, or about $30 billion. In other words, roughly 4 percent of all IT spending will go into Big Data-as-a-Service by 2021.""
Background of customer problem
Technical
Data collected and stored continues to grow exponentially
Data is available in many sources and formats
Traditional solutions are not planned for new requirements
Business
Opportunities to create innovative products and business models
Opportunity to gain business advantages
Financial

ÿ

Collecting the data fromÿmultiple sources is laborious, expensive and time consuming
Data is not cleaned and in the useful format
All customers do not have own resources or knowledge to collect and refine data
Customers want pay only what they consume

Business idea
Despite exponentially increase of open data available development of sustainable services has been modest
Value-added innovative services will be builtÿon top of Big Data (please see attached mockup.pdf more information) where customer can combining Big Data and own data (MyData)
Primary earning model is based on subscription or usage of data intensive products and datasets
Secondary earning model based on advertising companies brands and products (e.g. products and labels from childhood as a content of innovative product)
The business model is scalable and global

Provides scalable and efficient platform on data, analytics and service levels
Third parties can easily plug into the platform
Platform supports various usages
Data producers and customers are present in order to achieve critical mass of data

Benefits for customers
Broad access ? Broad access to datasets that otherwise would prove difficult to publish or consume
Agility ? Customers do not need extensive knowledge of underlying data.
Cost effectiveness ? Once dataset have been built it can be provided for multiple customers and customers pay only what they use
Data quality ? Data quality is controlled by the service provider. Once a new API and dataset have been tested properly changes can be managed reliably
ÿ
Data supply and demand
Supply
Open data and other available in carefully selected public data sources, the final range will be decided after the proto
Data from companies where available
Demand
Target customers are users/companies in need to combine Big Data and MyData
ÿ
Target Market
First proof of concept in Finland, next EMEA and then Global markets
ÿ
Competitors
It seems that there are not many direct competitor which combining Big Data and MyData. Below are some Big Data companies using Big Data for various purposes
e.g. http://www.wolframalpha.com/,ÿhttp://gnip.com/,ÿhttp://3roundstones.com/,ÿhttp://www.junar.com/
ÿ
Competitive advantages
Experienced team together with technical and business skills
All team members are owners of Omakirja, this means strong commitment towards the successful business
Competition is disorganized, there is lot of space for a new player in markets
There are only modest suistanable services combining Big and user's own data
The proof of concept can be tested by using a real customer (Omakirja)",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

147,CREA147,CREA,CREAtiFi,Spain,"Videodossier, S.L.",Kinologos,"Calle Dante Alighieri, 59, Bajos, 08032 Barcelona, Spain",Horizontal (solutions suitable for every verticals),0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Edgar Gallart,"In order to develop the Service we want to offer, we first have to develop an intelligent product consisting on an inexpensive multicamera System Set that allows anybody to record a conference at anytime. The portable System Set, already developed and functioning in laboratory environment, is composed of several ?Docking Plates? above which are attached the different cameras and audio recorders involved in the video recording session. The inexpensive servo-assited Docking Plates allow the cameras to automatically frame and focus the person(s) talking in the conference. The main achievement of the System Set resides, besides in its low price, in the fact of being able to collect information generated in the room (movements, noise, light shifts, etc) and convert it into parameters (metadata) which then make possible an automated edition with all the recorded material. Manual edition costs become therfore inexistent. Furthermore, after the video edition has been automatically accomplished, the conferences are directly uploaded to a server where the collaborative service is offered.

The Service ?basically? consists on a web platform that motivates collaborative transcriptions and translations of the videos by means of involving stakeholders of cultural entities. The intellectual involvement is accomplished by offering different types of remuneration (not only economical) to the targeted stakeholders. From tiny chops of transcriptions to complete translations, Stakeholders (Users, visitors, workers from the different cultural entities...) are invited to collaborate on an always growing legate of well indexed cultural videos.

The collaborative spirit shall only be possible if the videos of the different entities are all in the same web page thus making the one site a reference for all human beings who look for well indexed videos from experts willing to share their knowledge. In order to gather the different and diverse cultural entities in the same video platform, several studied issues have been taken into consideration. The three and most important opportunities that have to be clearly given to the potential Users (Corporations, Cultural entities and their stakeholders) are:
1) an undeniable money saver method in the recording and edition workflow for the corporations

2) an undeniable time saver method in the process of both indexing material (Entities) and finding interesting material (Users) 3) an elegant method for corporations to demonstrate to the public their concern for cultural issues (canalisation of CSR).

While the recording and edition workflow is certainly optimised by the ""Docking Plates"", the indexing process is facilitated as follows: the adoption by the Cultural Entities of the web video platform does not begin in the process of assisting the uploading of the media but rather in a much earlier stage, that is, from the moment the Entity is planning the Event. Thus, by the time the video is ready to be uploaded, there is no need to fill in again all the data involved in that item in order to have all the data well indexed (authors, sponsors, language, place...): The metadata is already in the video file when it?s time to show it online.ÿ",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

148,CREA148,CREA,CREAtiFi,Poland,e-volve sp. z o.o.,eREST,"Centralna 23a, lok 1, 44-240 ½ory, Poland",ACCOMMODATION AND FOOD SERVICE ACTIVITIES,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Marcin Wilk,"eRest is complex system, which combines few services from gastronomic area. Its main feature is providing restaurant menu directly to clients smartphonesÿ and receiving orders from them. This functionality is achieved by using Bluetooth markers, called beacons or simply by internet connection combined with GPS, built-in clients mobile devices. Both options will be connected with mobile application. This application will provide also few own features.
ÿÿÿÿÿÿÿÿÿÿÿ

First option is ?passive?, which means we can only show information without getting feedback. But, because of used technology it will be easy to connect with for clients, it won?t be necessary to have internet connection for clients or restaurant and it will be much more ?cool?. Also, because of low range of Bluetooth transmitters it will be possible to match different information in different places of restaurant. For example, near bar clients could receive only information about drinks and beverages.
ÿ

Second option offers much more flexibility. We plan to use GPS to automatically select right restaurant in client app. So, client simply goes into restaurant, starts our app and receives full information about served dishes, drinks, etc. He could then make his order, pay using online payment system and just wait. His order will be shown in restaurant kitchen.
ÿ

Those two systems could be combined. If we will have both of them installed in restaurant, we could send to kitchen more information like number of table which client chooses, without asking him about it.
ÿ

We plan to show information in attractive way to clients. Every position in menu will be supplemented by information about its history, how much calories it contains or even its recipe, if only chef gives permission for that. Another feature we plan to add is making favourite dishes list in application, which will allow clients to make orders even quicker in future. Our app also will be localized nearest restaurant with implemented eRest system by using GPS built-in mobile device.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

149,CREA149,CREA,CREAtiFi,Sweden,Funka Nu AB,MyAccessibility (an app for evaluation and planning for physical accessibility in museums),"D”belnsgatan, 21, 11140 Stockholm, Sweden","ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT AND RECREATION, PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION AND DEFENCE
column2: COMPULSORY SOCIAL SECURITY",B2B,5,14,YES,IN,"Susanna Laurin, CEO, Funka Nu AB","The project aims to develop an HTML5 web application to make measuring, checking and controlling accessibility in the built environment easy to use for non-specialists. Funka Nu AB already provide most of the content through Funka accessibility inventory database, but this project wants to convert this material into a multimodal app. The service and tool will support text, pictures, films, voice etc, on top of the common functionalities of smart phones (camera, gps-positioning etc), connected to the available free applications (such as Spirit Level, Light Meter and Sound Level meter) and the additional possibilities offered by the existing FIWARE-technology. With the cooperation of the National Museum of Science and Technology (Stockholm, Sweden) and more importantly its staff, we will be able to develop the service according to the needs and requirements of the potential customers real users",Tech provider,X,0,0,X,0,0,,Software,Content management,Applications,Content Applications,1,0,www.funkanu.com,0,0,funkanu.com

column1: 150,CREA150,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Kaista Networks Oy,Pilot for Netradar customer portal (NR Portal),"Eestintaival 18 D 21, 02280 Espoo, Finland",Horizontal (solutions suitable for every verticals),0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Jukka Manner,"Netradar is a global mobile measurement service with over 160'000 users.ÿIt's is a disctruptive technology platform for measuring mobile networks and devices. Our users measure the network by using our public Netradar service, designed by researchers at Aalto University in Finland. Kaista Networks serves consumers, regulators, serviceÿdevelopers, operators and manufacturers with our big data analysis based on Netradar.
ÿ

We can help operator business by providing accurate coverage maps based on the users? experienced network speeds and a comparison to competitors. Real-time 24/7 monitoring is also available.ÿThe measurements can be used to track the quality of the network, detect network failures and compare with the competitors.ÿ
ÿ

We have so far designed and implemented a public view of our data. On www.netradar.org consumers can browse coverage maps and that way compare offerings by mobile operators. Yet, we do not have any view or dashoard for business customers, where we could show much more details about the networks, even at the level of base stations and individual users
column2: how do they see the quality of a network ?

column1: ÿ

In this project, we will design and implement a commercial view to our data base on mobile networks and mobile devices. The portal (or dashboard) will have a real-time view of measurements performed by our users, and various statistics that are updated with the incoming real-time data. An additional export functionality would allow a business customer to retrieve a certain set of data to be used in internal analytics.
ÿ

152,CREA152,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Kunstdok Media Productions,Art Advisor,"El„inl„„k„rinkatu 3 , A 20, 00580 Helsinki, Finland","ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT AND RECREATION, Consumer leisure/gaming",0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Teemu Lindroos,"Art Advisor is the worlds first truly interactive, social and map based web- and mobile platform specialized in the consumption of visual arts. Its a platform that has intensely waited for its makers. Finally both professional artists and collectors, together with local residents and travellers, are able to find the best art around, intuitively and humanely.
ÿ

The map based platform is intuitive, fast and stylish. With it you can find close by museums, galleries and art events and all their basic information where ever you are. The complete art world of Europe is easily accessible, and easy to integrate to your travel plans. Its not just a search tool to find galleries, but a fully functional and new social platform, that aims to connect artists, art lovers, buyers and parties presenting art with each other. The application will make many conventions in the field obsolete, paper invitations and expensive and ineffective mass mailings will be a thing of the past. Email mailing lists will also get an upgrade, when the current mails of followed galleries and museums can be read straight from the service. You will never again miss an opening or the final days of a show.
ÿ

In addition to the application giving a quick glance of what is happening right now and where, there will also be sections for journalistic content and writings of art critique. In the current situation major newspapers and seldom published art journals have too much power over art criticism. And as a counterforce there has during the past years been published numerous online blogs that are specialized in writings on art. Our aim is to integrate the writings from these blogs as part of the application, in this way you can not only get the practical information for an exhibition, but also a critics review and comments from other users. In the longer run this will create an archive and a database on artists and their exhibitions. An archive that is accessible through the application long after the exhibition is over.
ÿ

The service will also give the art consumer an opportunity to raise there voice and express their opinion, hopefully inspiring other to experience art. We are currently researching different ways of integrating Facebook and Instagram as part of the application, enabling users to easily share interesting images and content related to art with each other. Encouraging the consumption of art as part of everyday life is our greatest wish! Maybe not least because we are active artists ourselves.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

Wimble makes this simple by combining all time management and productivity tools into one package, and it makes time management to be more productive, fun and easy through gamified, rewarding and engaging user experience. And this all, is free as Wimble is based on freemium logic and the monetization model focuses on micropayments.
ÿ

154,CREA154,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Vitalijs Stockmars TMI,Venue.Today,"F.E. Sillanpaankatu 2 A 4, 06100 Porvoo, Finland",Horizontal (solutions suitable for every verticals),0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,VItalyStockman,"I would like to develop a solution for two real problems that have been validated by my own experience and by results of my master thesis research:
ÿ

Today, it is challenging process to book business venue for an event such as training workshop, presentation, networking or social event, conference or other types ofÿevents. First, oneÿhas to do research e.g. online to find suitable venues
column2: then these venues need to be manually contacted by E-mail or by phone
column3: only after someÿwaiting for responses and more contacting a booking can be made. On average, this process requires making 5 calls just to check availability and pricing information and overall takes from several hours to several days of time.

column1: ÿ

Second problem is even bigger, affects well-being and happiness of society because it is related to efficient use of existing resources and ability to access desired resources: Today's average occupancy rate of business venues is only 40%. Most of the time venues are vacant.
ÿ
What these problems tell is that on one side, clients may not be booking as much as they wish because of difficulty or process
column2: on other side, venues managers are not renting their spaces as much as wish, because of lack of good simple to use tools.

column1: ÿ

Venue.Today is meant to solve the gap by introducing existing technologies, similar to the ones that are used to make real-time flight and hotel bookings, but in a new way, fine-tuned for the venue industry. Just like Steve Jobs applied touch screen technology (that existed for decades) to the mobile phone industry. He did not invent anything and was not even first, but he did it right and it was a big market shift.
ÿ
It will be a super simple to use and to understand site, accessible at this address http://venue.today.
Open Venue.Today
Enter Location, Date and Venue Sizeÿand press Search(other search parameters could be added later or hidden behind ""advanced search"")
Receiveÿa list of venues that match criteria together with real-time availability information and price
View venue profiles with images and descriptions and choose the most suitable one
Press Book and pay online with a credit card for instant confirmation E-mail.
ÿ
Process should take between 5 and 15 minutes and free the client from annoying calling, writing and waiting.
ÿ
!ÿExtra use case for event managers:
Event managers are potential ""super users"" of Venue.Today, because they need to book venues all the time.
Almost every medium and large size company is an event manager as they often have permanent event organizing staff.
Such users could have access to ""premium"" functionality to submit request to all venues that match defined criteria at once:
Event manager submits request, explaining venueÿsize, other parameters and filling description fieldÿabout other special custom needs such as catering, strong WIFI etc.
All venues that match criteria automatically receive notification about the request and have possibility to answer it with their best offer.
Event manager chooses best offer and makes booking, saving a lot of time and getting a better deal.
ÿ
Competitors
ÿ
After extensive research and analysis of competition, a number of potentially competing platforms were identified:
CVENT.com ? big US business, develops meeting management system and runs DB of venues.
ThatVenue.com ? Malaysian startup, limited geographically, nice design.
Konferencem.lv ? Latvian startup, limited geographically (Baltics).
VenueFinder.com ?ÿUKbusiness, sophisticated venue database.
Some others...
ÿ
However, not a single one of discovered competing platforms has real-time functionality which is the main concept of my proposed solution.
In other words, neither of discovered competitors is solving the described problem.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A
155,CREA155,CREA,CREAtiFi,Poland,Pixel Legend,Pastguide,"Falskiego, 27b/4, 70-733 Szczecin, Poland","ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT AND RECREATION, Consumer education/culture, PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION AND DEFENCE
column2: COMPULSORY SOCIAL SECURITYÿÿÿ",B2B/B2C,8,6,YES,IN,Jan Filipowiak,"Millions of us visit heritage centres every year but, despite using various tools, visits are not engaging and leave us disconnected with the story. Expensive guidebooks, audioguides or overly simplistic apps are not adding much value to the visit that often simply bore people. The Large part of the population for various reasons (social, economic, health) can?t travel to the physical location.

column1: ÿ

We want to develop a mobile app where we can witness the story of the visited place in 3D as geolocated, interactive 3D scene supported by augmented reality and image identification. Scenes will be matched by geolocation to current surroundings for the on-site visitors. Imagine pointing your tablet at the ruin and seeing the living castle in full glory. User will see reenacted, living enviroment with bustling cities, people on streets, famous characters guiding visitors and interactive, gamified tasks to complete and learn by play.
ÿ
Please check the video of the app prototype here: http://www.pastguide.com
ÿ

Scenes planned at 18 European Locations have the potential of reaching 127,5 mln physical visitors travelling there every year. (Scenes include: Collosseum, Notre Dame, Sacre Coeur, London Tower etc.) According to UNESCO, cultural and natural heritage tourism is ?the most rapidly growing international sector of the tourism industry?. OECD and UNWTO reports that cultural tourism accounts for 40% of all international tourism worldwide.
ÿ

Pastguide will be offered by heritage site operator directly on rented device or for download. It will be also available in app stores and online for people who can?t travel.ÿScene promotion will be handled on-site by the heritage site operator, who will get their share of income from downloads, reducing our marketing costs significantly.
ÿ

There are 125 Millions of users visiting 18 scenes we have planned first 5 years. Each will have a chance to buy Pastguide for around 3 euros. Half of this will go to us, half to site operator. Other options are available - licensing to operator etc.
ÿ

The market is not saturated yet. Most companies produce content featuring still, static architecture. These companies are mostly for hire.There?s no direct competitor offering real life scenes from the past with people that geolocate user on his mobile device and let him interact with the virtual characters.
ÿ
We have following advantages over competition:
1st to market -ÿThere?s no app featuring reenactments of events and people
Strong partnerships -ÿPartner museums and users receive share in profits and development for free.
Quality -ÿOur scenes are designed to show AAA game quality
Gamification -ÿComplete quests and achievements and share with friends
Adoption potential - travelling tourists, virtual tourists, multiplatform
ÿ
We face following risks:
Competing solutions - Fast implementation and time to reach the market is the key to secure a safe position.
Pitching Heritage sites - In our model heritage site operator gets scene development for free and his share of income from each download of his scene.

Indifference of mobile users - Pastguide will tackle this barrier by relying on heritage site partnerships during the first 5 years.",Tech provider,X,0,0,X,0,0,,Software,Authoring and Publishing Software,Applications,Content Applications,1,0,http://www.pastguide.com,0,50000,pastguide.com

156,CREA156,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Versoteq 3D Solutions Oy,Tactile maps community,"Finnoonniitynkuja 4, 02270 Espoo, Finland","Consumer health/wellness, HUMAN HEALTH AND SOCIAL WORK ACTIVITIES",B2B/B2C,2,2,YES,IN,Timo Juhani Yletyinen,"General description

The business idea is to build a web site for developing, sharing, shopping and ordering of tactile maps for the visually impaired people. The competition in the market is based on old technology while Versoteq?s service will take into use modern web tools and 3D printing. In addition we will connect the customers with the providers of the maps (3D developers and tactile map specialists) efficiently from around the world. The solution advantages: 1) The customers will get the maps for a fair price compared to traditional maps, 2) site community and Versoteq?s specialists will guarantee that the map quality on the site is high and takes blind?s special requirements into account, 3) 3D designers will get freelancer work, or even small companies may specialice in providing such maps to the site, 4) the quality and processes already been developed by Versoteq will be adopted widely and rapidly and will help to improve the quality of life of the visually impaired.
ÿ
The business idea

The income to Versoteq comes from brokering the design assignments and mandatory quality consultation (10% of the trade) and brokering finished tactile maps from the site library (5? fixed price per map). The details of the projected turnover and income are in the atteched plan. The business is first launched inside Europe but nothing prevents from spreading the site service throughout the world.
ÿ

In the future the site operations can be used also for creating maps for people with normal vision, for advertising or normal guiding uses. 164,CREA164,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Scoopinion Oy,FindMushroom - App for tourists and locals to easily find mushrooms via open map and weather data,"It„inen Teatterikuja 5, A12, 00100 Helsinki, Finland",Consumer other,0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Johannes Koponen,"FindMushrooms helps tourists and local tourists to find mushrooms easily, using publicly available open data and weather information to count probable mushroom growing spots. The competitive advantage comes from the learning algorithm that crunches large amounts of location specific weather data and open data about forest types and forest shadows (hills, forest density).
ÿ
Customers

43% of Finns collect mushrooms each autumn (Finnish Forest Institute,ÿSource in Finnish). FindMushroom app is meant for the least experienced mushroom collectors, but it can be used even by the professionals. The spearhead user is a urban dweller who would like to spend a day out in the nearby forests but is unsure where to go.
ÿ
Value Proposition

FindMushrooms promises that the users won?t come back home empty handed. By improving accessibility, convenience and reducing risks it makes a good sense for people to download the free app and rent the nearby mushroom location information from the service.
ÿ
Customer relationship
Customer feedback is used to optimize the learning algorithm that combines the used datasets.
ÿ
Channels
Awareness

Service is advertised in mushroom picking hotspots, i.e. parking slots and public transportation stops that are near known mushroom picking places, such as Palohein„ and Nuuksio. Likewise, the service is mentioned in relevant online communities. With the service, people are also able to share their mushroom picking spots, further increasing the awareness of the product.
ÿ
Evaluation of the value proposition
The app is free and the most mushroom location information is sold via in-app purchases. Thus, users are able to get to know the app before they purchase the information.
ÿ
Renting the mushroom location database

Mushroom location information is updated constantly due to known growing periods, rain information and lighting information (based on landscape shadows, clouds and forest density). Thus, the mushroom location information deprecates rather fast. This is why it makes sense to sell information snapshots via easy in-app purchases.
ÿ
After sales
It is possible to advertise new locations and good times to go to collect mushrooms via push notifications.
ÿ
Key activities and key resources

Key activity is establishing a solid foundation for the algorithm that collects relevant open data and confirms and disregards findings based on user feedback. This key activity provides a competitive advantage: this intellectual capital is the key resource. The intellectual capital includes ever-increasing knowledge on spatio-temporal mushroom locations and constantly improving algorithm in guessing the correct locations. This is very difficult to copy. Installed free apps provide customer contact channel that can be used to encourage users to collect mushroom in the following autumn as well.
ÿ
Key partners

Key partners include the providers of open data, especially National Land Survey of Finland (growing spot information and shadow information), Finnish Meteorological Institute and Finnish Food safety authority Evira (mushroom information). ÿÿÿ
ÿ
Cost structure

Cost structure in FindMushrooms is based on (somewhat) fixed costs that include platform maintenance and customer feedback costs and variable costs including server maintenance, data handling and calculations, research and development costs and, most importantly, advertisement costs.
ÿ
Revenue streams

Revenue streams in FindMushrooms are based on providing temporal access to mushroom location database. This means it is volume dependent fixed pricing. If the service becomes very successful in certain key areas, it is possible to change to yield management based pricing, as mushrooms are eventually a limited resource",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A

165,CREA165,CREA,CREAtiFi,Finland,Exove Design Ltd,Doing,"It„merenkatu, 1, 00180 Helsinki, Finland",Horizontal (solutions suitable for every verticals),0,#N/A,#N/A,NO,0,Aki-Ville P”yki”,"Factors that drive value in a company have been mostly perceived to be growth, profit, ROI and other hard financial values. Those values do determine the financial growth and situation of a company, however the problem with this view in today?s world is that the economy is more and more reliant on the knowhow, relationships and people themselves as an asset. This is especially true in the creative industry. These kind of soft values are intangible and hard to measure. Everyone knows that people who feel happy are more likely to put more effort into their work than people who feel down. Similarly, fast-paced work can cause both positive and negative stress, depending on how much satisfaction people get out of their work.
ÿ

Doing collects data on the wellbeing and satisfaction of employees and empowers companies and institutes to use this as a tool of overall performance measurement. Doing is an app that allows people to anonymously indicate their mood and well-being on a daily basis. The app is based on ease of interaction and a combination of factors that, in our view, are the causes of both professional satisfaction and dissatisfaction. To summarize, Doing is using quantified self to improve one?s professional productivity.
ÿ

We believe our solution, Doing, can completely transform the way creative people, teams and companies can be measured and lead by collecting and analyzing softer and bigger data than typical money/time based metrics can offer to companies.
ÿ
Target market

Doing brings a tool for measuring employee wellbeing and performance tracking for creative industries. Creativity is hard to measure and even harder to put a price on. By the data and analytics that will be developed with Doing, the companies can foresee their productivity and estimate and increase employee satisfaction. The institution view shows the data anonymously without the company being able to track individuals, but rather the overall mood of a crowd.
ÿ
Doing will be developed from the start with an international mindset and our goal is to launch our beta App with at least one international partner in August 2015.
ÿ
Competitors

At the moment similar analytics are done through collecting customer satisfaction on-site (http://www.happy-or-not.com/). However, just by pressing a smiley -icon doesn?t tell you much deeper analytics or a person?s satisfaction. A smiley can indicate different things to different people and doesn?t tell us the reasons behind the mood. Overall moods of people are being analysed through Twitter texts and are illustrated through wider data analysis (http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/22/tracking-u-s-mood-through-twitter/). This can be useful in wider context and when measuring a distinct group of people that are in the reach of and using social media.
ÿ

But when you are targeting a group of individuals from various backgrounds and searching for tools for employee satisfaction, no easy solution exists. Doing aims to this niche in the creative industry by bringing a tool to collect and monitor data on the factors that influence people?s wellbeing at work.
ÿ
Business Model

The goal is first to examine what benefits creative companies can get out of their employees wellbeing data and how these can be connected with the overall performance of a company. Secondly our goal is to verify the business model. We believe that for individual users, Doing should be free. We believe that ultimately the businesses will be willing to pay on the use of the data that Doing collects as it will bring direct savings for them through improved employee satisfaction.",0,,0,0,0,0,0,,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,#N/A,1,0,#N/A,#N/A,0,#N/A
